dataset.title: Chemistry data for lakes and lakes, inlets/outlets samples collected summer 1988, Arctic LTER, Toolik Research Station, Alaska.

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology

abstract.para: Yearly file describing the samples collected at various sites near Toolik Research Station (68 38'N, 149 36'W). Sample site descriptors include an assigned number (sortchem), site, date, time, depth, distance, elevation, treatment, date-time,category, and water type (lake, surface, soil). Physical measures collected in the field include temperature (water, soil, well water), conductivity, pH, average thaw depth, well height, discharge, stage height, and light (lakes). Chemical analysis for the sample include alkalinity; dissolved inorganic and organic carbon (DIC and DOC); inorganic and total dissolved nutrients (NH4, PO4, NO3, TDN, TDP); particulate carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus (PC, PN, and PP); cations (Ca, Mg, Na, K, and Si); anions (SO4 and Cl); and oxygen. Chlorophyll a was collected at stream sites and for experimental manipulations.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Toolik Lake Research Area, North Slope, Alaska (approximately 68 degrees 38'N, 149 degrees 34'W; elevation approximately 719 m)

description.para: Entered metadata into new metadata form.
Version 4: LTERNET Data Access server proxy changed from das.lternet.edu to metacat.lternet.edu.
Ver. 5 Add the other enitity to the eml describing the Excel file so the DAS can return the correct file name. JimL 4Mar09.
Version 6: Jim L Feb 2010 No info on this version number

Ver 6: G. Kling, 28Feb2010: updated entire file. J. Kostrzewski, 04Nov09: updated SO4, Cl, Ca, Ma, Na, K, and Si values. Previously, values were entered as ppm, they are now reported as uM. Updated metadata header and explanation information to reflect the changes made above.

para.literalLayout: For water sampling protocol, see the Land-Water protocol accessible from the Land-Water mainpage on the Arctic LTER web page or at http://www-personal.umich.edu/~gwk/protocol_v25.pdf. Specific methodologies are the protocol book listed above and a general description is provided below.General analyses: inorganic nutrients (NH4 and PO4) were analyzed by wet chemistry techniques at Toolik Field Station. Gas samples were analyzed at Toolik Field Station. Beginning in 2006, DIC samples were acidified in the field and analyzed on a gas chromatographer at Toolik Field Station. DOC, DIC (prior to 2006), TDN, TDP, particulates, and ions were brought back to the University of Michigan for analysis. DOC are run on a Shimadzu TOC-5000. Particulate Carbon and Nitrogen on a Perkin Elmer CHN 2400, most TDN and TDP are run at the University of Michigan on an Alpkem autoanaylzer, ions on a Dionex ion chromatograph, and cations on an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). Starting in 1997, alkalinity samples were run on a Radiometer autotitrator either at Toolik Field Station or in Michigan. Prior to 1999 the phenate method was used to analyze the ammonium content. In the years 1999-2001 a comparison study of the OPA method and the phenate method were performed. Starting in 2002, OPA was used to analyze ammonium content.

protocol.title: Field and Lab Methods and Protocols, Kling lab, University of Michigan

project.title: Arctic Long-Term Ecological Research (ARC LTER) Program

para.literalLayout:
The goal of Arctic LTER project is to predict the future ecological characteristics of the site based upon our knowledge of the controls of ecosystem structure and function as exerted by physical setting and geologic factors, climatic factors, biotic factors, and the changes in fluxes of water and materials from land to water. To achieve this goal the Arctic LTER uses several approaches:
Long-term monitoring and surveys of natural variation of ecosystem characteristics in space and time. Includes: climate, plant communities and productivity, thaw depth, stream flow, chemistry of streams and lakes, temperatures of streams and lakes, lake chlorophyll lake productivity, zooplankton abundance.
Experimental manipulation of ecosystems for years and decades. Includes: tundra warming, shading, and fertilizing, grazer exclusions, fertilization of lakes and streams, addition and subtraction of predators.
Synthesis of results and predictive modeling at ecosystem and watershed scales. Includes: stream N cycling, lake physics, bioenergetics of fish populations, water movement and transfer of DOC and nutrients from land to water, soil respiration, cycling and storage of C in tundra under different scenarios of future climates.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grants #DEB-981022, 9211775, 8702328; #OPP-9911278, 9911681, 9732281, 9615411, 9615563, 9615942, 9615949, 9400722, 9415411, 9318529; #BSR 9019055, 8806635, 8507493. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The Arctic LTER research site (68°N and 149°W) is in the foothills region of the North Slope of Alaska and includes the entire Toolik Lake watershed and the adjacent watershed of the upper Kuparuk River, down to the confluence of these two watersheds. This area is typical of the northern foothills of the Brooks Range, with continuous permafrost, no trees, a complete snow cover for 7 to 9 months, winter ice cover on lakes, streams, and ocean, and cessation of river flow during the winter. Tussock tundra vegetation of sedges and grasses mixed with dwarf birch and low willows form the dominant vegetation type with areas of drier heath tundra on ridge tops and other well-drained sites as well as areas of river-bottom willow communities.

dataTable.entityDescription: Chemistry data for lakes and lakes, inlets/outlets samples collected summer 1988, Arctic LTER, Toolik Research Station, Alaska.

attribute.attributeDefinition: A unique number assigned to each sample collected at a specific site at a specific date and time. The year that the sample was collected is followed by a dash and then a sequential number. For example, if 600 samples were collected in 2002, then the first sample collected is 2002-0001 and the last sample is 2002-0600.

textDomain.definition: A unique number assigned to each sample collected at a specific site at a specific date and time. The year that the sample was collected is followed by a dash and then a sequential number. For example, if 600 samples were collected in 2002, then the first sample collected is 2002-0001 and the last sample is 2002-0600.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Site Name. If a soil site, the site is described in the name by general location then specific feature (watertrack,etc) then specific point (1,2,3,...). If a lake or streams site, the lake or stream name (as it is commonly known) is given. Exceptions in naming procedure are provided in the Code Information and in AK-LTER_Site_Info.xls.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Distance along a stream where negative values are upstream of a designated starting point and positive values are downstream of the designated starting point. For soil sites, the distance is the perpendicular distance from the river or lake shore.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Fluorescence estimate of Chlorophyll a corrected for phaeopigment (phaeophytin). This acidification method was started in 1999, and applied to all samples in this spreadsheet (landwater) by 2000. Note that the lakes Arcitc LTER group started this method in 2004.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Fluorescence estimate of Phaeopigment estimated by acidification of a chlorophyll sample.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Fluorescence estimate of Chlorophyll a without a phaeopigment correction (no acidification). This was this historical measure use by the Arctic LTER and previous studies of Toolik Lake. Chla_Raw = (((Sample Fluorescence - Blank) * Slope) - Intercept) * (Acetone_ml / Sample Volume Filtered)

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)
.=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

attribute.attributeDefinition: PAR (photosynthetically active radiation) measured above water surface (in air).

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

attribute.attributeDefinition: PAR (photosynthetically active radiation) measured below the water surface.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Coefficient of light attenuation (extinction coefficient). This is estimated by regression of PAR light in water versus depth (meters). Units are in per meter (meter-1)

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

attribute.attributeDefinition: Average active layer thaw depth using 3 independent measurements (Thaw 1, Thaw 2, and Thaw 3) all taken within 50-100 cm from the sampling site. All measurements are made in inter-tussock areas with a steel probe.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: .=not measured, written down in field, or not analyzed (sample lost,...)

otherEntity.entityDescription: An excel file that has worksheets with the metadata and data.

unit.name: microequivalentPerLiter
unit.description: concentration of charge (on dissolved ions). A single multiplier to SI is not possible

unit.name: micromolePerLiter
unit.description: µM = µmoles per liter of solution

unit.name: microEinsteinPerMeterSquaredPerSecond
unit.description: micromoles (1E-06 moles of photons) per square meter per second (radiant flux density)
